content.description:
Traverse left from the far right. Mantle where ever but for full value traverse the whole thing.

Hard not to slip off this sticky rock!
content.protection: A couple pads to protect the whole thing solo or one pad and a spotter to move it.
content.location: Near the bottom middle of the boulder field. Downhill a ways and slightly skiers left of Wise Up Wall

content.description: Climb the chimney! Short and sweet. Would be 3 stars if it was longer. Still great as an intro to chimneys.
content.protection: Maybe a pad and a spotter for exiting the chimney but not necessary

content.description:
Find the lowest hand jams you can and then make a few more steep and reachy hand jams until you can grab the lip jug. Super fun!

Take care to pad the back breaker of a rock. Not an issue with a pad and attentive spotter though.

Climb the little lump next to the start of Purdy Mouth.

Sit or stand start.
content.location: Just left of Purdy Mouth and Overbite

content.description:
This is a very unique and must do experience! A mix of spelunking and chimney climbing await the adventurous.

Enter from the northern side. Side step your way through the chasm until you see daylight on the other side. Chimney climb up the southern side of the boulder. Many ways to do this but the most convenient path can be found where a leftward leaning diagonal crack on the eastern side provides good hand holds to get established.
content.location:
From the main trail just after rounding bend past Main Wall head down among the boulders. Scramble over to the largest boulder with the obvious wide crack down the middle.

Enter from the northern side. The chimney crack runs through a large roof with a gnarly looking chockstone that looms overhead.

pathTokens: Hwy 20 and North Cascades National Park
* Bouldering in the Cumberland Crags Area
